results.title: No worries
results.creator_credit: David Elfick, Eric Fellner, Southern Star Entertainment, Initial (GB) and Palm Beach Pictures
results.brief_description: The courage of Ben and Ellen Beel and their 11-year-old daughter, Matilda, has seen them through countless misfortunes in a country plagued by the harsh elements. Drought is again parching the Australian outback with devastating consequences, and having barely survived the recession of the early 1990’s, the Bells now face an ever tumbling wool price dwindling their profits and their sheep dying of starvation. When all seems lost and they must leave their beloved home to move to the city, the never-say-die Aussie spirit triumphs - no worries!
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Elfick, Eric Fellner, Southern Star Entertainment, Initial (GB) and Palm Beach Pictures

results.title: No way they want to slow down
results.creator_credit: Giles Walker, Tom Daly, Desmond Dew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This documentary takes an informal look at how the best skiers work and live. The Canadian Ski Team is on a tight schedule down in Chile and Argentina. Two and a half tons of equipment, speeds of up to 140 km/h, gruelling work-outs, and a dramatic theft are all par for the course. And what a course. Downhill racing is definitely not for the timid. Commentary by John Lang.

results.title: No strangers here
results.creator_credit: K Sternberg, Dept of Immigration and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Dealing with the problem of assimilation of migrants, the film shows how newcomers to Australia are finding new friends and happiness in the land of their adoption through the co-operation and sympathetic understanding of ordinary citizens. They begin their new life in a country town and through the personal interest of the editor of the newspaper, the newcomers become part of the life of the community.

results.title: No sex, no violence, no news
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Stefan Moore and Film Australia
results.brief_description: No sex, no violence, no news is the programing policy of China’s biggest satellite TV network. Following producers, distributors, satellite moguls and advertising executives, this documentary looks at how business is conducted in a strange world where official party propaganda merges with Hollywood and MTV. The competition is fierce in the struggle to access China’s huge television audience and rapidly expanding consumer market. This program explores the impact of global TV on modern China, offering a fascinating insight into Chinese society and values.

results.title: No reason to stay
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at the school drop-out and what they drop out from. A deliberately biased look at today’s educational system and how it fails, if it does, to give young people the preparation they need for adult life when school doors close behind them. A provocative film for all concerned with the course of education.

results.title: No quick fix
results.creator_credit: Peter McEvoy, Paul Costello and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: At the time of making this documentary (1999) it was estimated that upto 1,000 heroin users in Australia would die before the ambulance reached them. Here we follow a handful of heroin addicted patients through the pilot stage of one of the world’s first scientific trials of Naltrexone, the controversial new drug being offered as an alternative to Methadone treatment, at Westmead Hospital in western Sydney. The trial is headed by Dr Jon Currie, neurologist and addiction specialist, who believes that Naltrexone could be the long term answer to Heroin addiction. Unlike Methodone, which is addictive, Naltrexone acts as a block to the receptors in the brain which Heroin acts on - in other words, it blocks the craving. However, although it is easy to get patients started on the treatment, the hard part is the follow-up and rehabilitation. If there is no support and counselling, the patient will often stop their Naltrexone treatment. It is made very clear that patient behaviour will not change unless they stay on the Naltrexone for several months - that Naltrexone is not a quick fix! Contains sequences with heroin addicts talking about their addiction, discussing Naltrexone treatment with Dr Currie, and actual footage of first stages of treatment including rapid detox, withdrawal and recovery. Reporter: Peter McEvoy.

results.title: No place to go
results.creator_credit: Boris Holtzman, G Lauzren, Edward Magruder Jones, Vincent Tovell, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Mexico exemplifies one of the developing world’s major problems, the serious impact of rural migrants on cities of every size. Cities containing industry are becoming increasingly less viable as unskilled people from the country swarm to them in search of jobs and a decent living standard. As automation cuts even deeper into work opportunities, overpopulated cities face growing crisis’s. The U. N. World Food program is assisting Mexico in promoting labour intensive “food-for-work” projects designed to encourage rural people to stay where they are by raising rural living standards. Mexico is also bringing light industry to the countryside in the hope of raising rural incomes to Mexico City levels.

results.title: No problems
results.creator_credit: Jackie McKimmie, Queensland Film Development Office and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Mercy Steele remembers her childhood in Lowmead, Queensland in the 1920’s. Born on 10th March 1921, Mercy’s time with her mother was cut short when her mother died giving birth to her younger sister - her father eventually walked out on the family, leaving Mercy’s granny to look after the two girls. The film is a visual representation of Mercy’s childhood memories set in the lush landscape of Northern Queensland. This romantic view of a landscape mirrors the romantic view of what was in reality a harsh life. Storyteller and singer: Mercy Steele (Awards: Sydney Film Festival, 1990; St Kilda Film Festival, 1991)
